textRegions.text: learning the basics of the jME3 scene graph
What the scene graph is and what a spatial is
What a geometry is and how its appearance is defined
What a node is and what a parent - child relation is
How to organize the scene graph visually and logically using nodes
How to hide single spatials or whole parts of the scene graph
The scene graph is the virtual space that your game happens in
The objects in the scene graph are called spatials
Spatials have a translation (location), a rotation and a scale
The locations in the scene graph are defined using X, Y and Z coordinates
Y is upwards, X is right and Z is towards you
a spatial with a zero location and rotation
you can move the spatial using e.g. spatial.move(1, 1, 0);
the spatial has been moved (translated) along the x and y axes
you can rotate the spatial around the z axis by using e.g. spatial.rotate(0, 0, FastMath.HALF_PI);
the spatial has been rotated around the z axis
you can scale the spatial by using e.g. spatial.scale(2);
visible objects in the scene graph
A geometry is the type of spatial that is actually visible on the screen
A geometry has a mesh to define its form and a material to define the appearance
a geometry with a monkey mesh and white material
you can set a new material to the geometry by using e.g. geometry.setMaterial(redMaterial);
the same geometry with a new material
A node is a spatial that can have other spatials as children
The children of the node are moved and rotated relative to their parent node
The scene graph for example uses a base root node that all spatials are connected to
a node with a zero location and rotation
we attach a child spatial using node.attachChild(spatial);
the child spatial is attached to the node
now we move the child spatial using spatial.move(0, 1, 0);
the child spatial has been translated along the y axis
the child spatial now has a local translation relative to the node
now we move the node using node.move(1.5, 0, 0);
the node has been translated along the x axis
the child spatial moves along with it, keeping its local translation relative to the node
now we rotate the node by 90 around the z axis using node.rotate(0, 0, FastMath.HALF_PI);
the node has been rotated around the z axis
the child spatial rotates along with it, keeping its local translation and rotation relative to the node
now we rotate the child by -90 around the z axis using spatial.rotate(0, 0, -FastMath.HALF_PI);
the child spatial has been rotated around the z axis
the child spatial now has a local rotation relative to the node
now we rotate the node back by -90 around the z axis using node.rotate(0, 0, -FastMath.HALF_PI);
the node has been rotated back around the z axis
the child spatial keeps its local translation and rotation relative to the node
now we scale the node using node.scale(2);
the node has been scaled, the child spatial scales with it
note that the local translation of the child spatial is affected by the scale of its parent node too
now we scale the child spatial using spatial.scale(0.5);
the local translation of the child spatial is still the same, scaled by the parent node
the scale of the node is still doubled by the parent node, however the effective world size is now the same as before because the local scale of the node halves the size again
using nodes to organize the scene graph
the root node in a normal scene
like any node it can have other spatials, e.g. nodes as children
these nodes in turn can have other nodes and spatials as children as well
this allows organizing the scene graph visually and spatially
for example by grouping spatials to move them
but this also allows organizing the scene graph logically
in this case the translations and rotations of the nodes would most probably be zero
this way all translation and rotation values for the children can be used in the same local space
but lets go back to the structural overview (the nodes still have zero locations)
when looking for a certain NPC the only spatials we have to look in are the children of the NPCs node, e.g. Spatial enemy = npcNode.getChild(Enemy);
when looking for a mobile object the only spatials we have to look in are the children of the Mobile node, e.g. Spatial enemy = mobileNode.getChild(Enemy);
when we want to do e.g. a ray collision check with the world thats easy too, all world objects are grouped in the Immobile node CollisionResults results = immobileNode.collideWith(ray);
Culling means that a geometry is not rendered by the graphics card
The geometry is still processed as part of the scene graph but all rendering-related operations are suspended
A spatial can have a cull state of always, never or inherit (which is the default)
lets look at a normal scene
we can cull houseOne using houseOne.setCullHint(CullHint.Always);
house one has been culled and is not visible
we can make houseOne visible again using houseOne.setCullHint(CullHint.Inherit);
both houseOne and houseTwo become invisible because their cull hint is set to inherit by default
we can set the cull hint of houseTwo to never using houseTwo.setCullHint(CullHint.Never);
this makes houseTwo visible again, it is not influenced by the cull state of its parent immobileNode anymore
we can set the cull hint of immobileNode back to inherit like this immobileNode.setCullHint(CullHint.Inherit);
which makes both houses visible again
jMonkeyEngine3 automatically culls geometries that are not in the view of the camera
all geometries are visible to the camera, none are culled
the camera has been moved and now only the house is in its view frustum
the other geometries are culled automatically

Thank you for reading, this is a work in progress, any input is very welcome - Normen
